refsect1.title: Summary
refsect1.para: The min operator selects the minimum value from an array attribute.

note.para: The min operator provides the same functionality as the min aggregate. For details, see the min aggregate reference.

informalexample.para: This example finds the minimum value of each row of a 2-dimensional array.

step.para: Create a 1-attribute, 2-dimensional array called m3x3:--afl CREATE ARRAY m3x3 <val:double>[i=0:2,3,0,j=0:2,3,0]; --show-output=no
Store random values in m3x3:--afl store(build(m3x3,random()%20+1),m3x3); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yes --show-output-in-test-file=no
Select the minimum value of each row of m3x3:--afl min(m3x3,val,i); --output-format=dense --show-output-in-test-file=no

informalexample.para: Continuing on with this example, we can retrieve the minimum value, along with its position in the array, by using the following query:--afl project(filter(deldim(cross_join(aggregate(m3x3,min(val) as m),m3x3)),val=m),val); --show-output=no

step.para: Find the minimum value, and alias it so that we can use it in a cross join:--afl aggregate(m3x3,min(val) as m) --show-output-in-test-file=no
Cross join the minimum value with the original array, so that cell {i,j}x becomes {i,i,j}(m=min,x):--afl cross_join(aggregate(m3x3,min(val) as m),m3x3) --show-output-in-test-file=no
Remove the extra dimension added in the previous step:--afl deldim(cross_join(aggregate(m3x3,min(val) as m),m3x3)) --show-output-in-test-file=no

Filter (select) the cells that have the actual minimum value:--afl filter(deldim(cross_join(aggregate(m3x3,min(val) as m),m3x3)), val=m); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yes --show-output-in-test-file=no

Of the correct cells, show only val, not the alias, m:--afl project(filter(deldim(cross_join(aggregate(m3x3,min(val) as m),m3x3)), val=m),val); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yes --show-output-in-test-file=no
